author: Arsenal~Fanatic
content:
I am not an eternal optimist. I am a realistic sort of guy. Title is lost already imho. Tottenham are there to be taken but they are playing at White hart lane and they are going to be super motivated to beat us no matter the circumstances. My heart says we will win but my mind says it is going to be a high scoring draw. It would be interesting to see the team Wenger picks on Tuesday against Bayern which can have lot of says on both our physical and mental preparation for the NLD.

Our form has been dismal in the league. We beat Sunderland but lost away to Stoke, got spanked by Liverpool, drew against a hapless out of form, out of sorts United at the Emirates. We need to get our tactics right cos they have the players to hurt us. We simply cannot go out and commit forward the sort of numbers we did against Everton cos it can really backfire. This games is going to be a high tempo end to end stuff and playing Arteta in this one will not be a wise idea. I hope Ramsey is back for this and i want him to partner Flamini in the middle of the park. As i said the game against Bayern is more of a distraction than a help.

I think Wenger got the tactics spot on against Everton by pinning their fullbacks back and exploiting space left in behind and I think adopting similar tactics against Spurs will work considering how big a liability Kyle Walker is. Flamini looks worse than Arteta in fast paced games IMO, he was poor yesterday and against City earlier on this season both in end to end games. Arteta does a better job than Flamini at stopping the counter too, Flamini seemed to stop doing this after his yellow yesterday. I'd start Flamini against Bayern because they'd probably have more of the ball and he has a better engine.

author: VAVAVOOM 14
content:
Szczesny
Sagna Merts Kosh Gibbs
Ramsey Flamini
Chamberlain Ozil Cazorla
Sanogo

Well do these cu*ts, been too long (7 years) since we beat them at WHL in the league.

They play Benfica in the Europa League on Thursday, meaning they'll only have two days rest before this game. We need to win this to keep our title hopes alive - we have to win virtually all our remaining games if we're to have any hopes of doing so and this game is no exception. This season, Tottenham have been outscored 23-2 on aggregate by teams in the top 4, we need to put them to the sword.

If we score first, expect their crowd to turn on them and become volatile - despite all the humiliating losses they've suffered this year, defeat at the hands of us would be the most painful of all. Lets make it happen and keep our (slim) title charge alive.

P.S.

So happy/relieved to have Ramsey back for this, feels like I'm about to be reunited with a long lost friend.

author: elovic
content:
Hi guys.

I rarely post anything here, although visiting this forum multiple times a day. I've been carefully trying to articulate a thought that I have been carrying for months now, trying not to get my "feelings" involved, but - am I the only one who thinks Arteta has been mostly useless this past season?

I'm sure most of you will say that he organizes the back midfield and he is a responsible midfielder and an asset. But not only is he invisible for the most part of every game, but he rarely contributes anything to both our attacking play or defensive play. I don't have statistics infront of me, as I am not trying to build a case here, just raising this question to see if anyone else feels this way. I confidently argue that replacing Arteta with a far more dynamic midfielder (Rosicky, Ox, even Flamini) would turn our entire team-play around.

Me personally? I can't look beyond all these pretentious excuses trying to defend Arteta in being anything but a slot filler. I'd love for any one of you friends to counter me with statistics, maybe I'm wrong. But I've watched almost every minute of every Arsenal game this season, and he has never impressed me or convinced me that he is worthy of a spot. Cleverley MKII.

I confidently argue that replacing Arteta with a far more dynamic midfielder (Rosicky, Ox, even Flamini) would turn our entire team-play around.

Me personally? I can't look beyond all these pretentious excuses trying to defend Arteta in being anything but a slot filler. I'd love for any one of you friends to counter me with statistics, maybe I'm wrong. But I've watched almost every minute of every Arsenal game this season, and he has never impressed me or convinced me that he is worthy of a spot. Cleverley MKII.[/quote]

I completely understand your feelings mate. Arteta is a fantastic team man, is a tidy passer but he is not an out and out holding player. He has clearly been on a downhill slide this season. His legs have deserted him which has led to him being exposed time and again. this problem gets compounded in a league like the Premier league which requires a lot of running and tracking. He has clearly past his best and is getting picked more on past reputation than on current form and fitness. I agree with you in that he is clearly not starter quality. I just hope and pray the club does not extend his contract as he is a near liability when the tempo hots up. Yesterdays game was a classic example where all he did was sit back without making any effort to close in or tackle and despite that he has got such high ratings its ludicrous. As i have said our expectations have gone so low these days that on account of us constantly underachieving in the last 8-9 years.

author: Zedie
content:
[quote]elovic wrote:
Hi guys.

I rarely post anything here, although visiting this forum multiple times a day. I've been carefully trying to articulate a thought that I have been carrying for months now, trying not to get my "feelings" involved, but - am I the only one who thinks Arteta has been mostly useless this past season?

I'm sure most of you will say that he organizes the back midfield and he is a responsible midfielder and an asset. But not only is he invisible for the most part of every game, but he rarely contributes anything to both our attacking play or defensive play. I don't have statistics infront of me, as I am not trying to build a case here, just raising this question to see if anyone else feels this way. I confidently argue that replacing Arteta with a far more dynamic midfielder (Rosicky, Ox, even Flamini) would turn our entire team-play around.

Me personally? I can't look beyond all these pretentious excuses trying to defend Arteta in being anything but a slot filler. I'd love for any one of you friends to counter me with statistics, maybe I'm wrong. But I've watched almost every minute of every Arsenal game this season, and he has never impressed me or convinced me that he is worthy of a spot. Cleverley MKII.[/quote]

You are not alone in being disappointed with arteta this season.

I feel he has regressed a lot this season and has had many more poor games than good pr excellent ones.

I dont mind being proven wrong eithers via certain stats, but then stats dont always tell the whole truth.

A player could make 99 out of 100 passes in a game, but the 1 stray pass could lead to the goal that lost you points instead of getting all 3. Looking at those stats, you wouldnt know.

For me, Arteta needs to be replaced in the summer with a player we actually needed last summer. A disciplined brute that can pick the occassional pass forward.

His engine, acceleration and recovery speed is an increasing concern to me and it needs to be addressed as a priority after a striker.

author: THFC6061
content:
[IMG]http://img.photobucket.com/albums/v239/jyarden/2013/A6536_zps5237fa24.jpg[/IMG]

Tottenham Hotspur host Arsenal at White Hart Lane on Sunday 16th March 2014 (KO 16:00) in the 30th match of the 2013-14 Premier League season.

Spurs come into the game in 5th place in the Table on 53 points with Arsenal in 3rd on 59 points. This will be the 254th time the two teams have met.

Spurs v Arsenal is now one of the great rivalries in World Football but the fixture had very different beginnings back in November 1887 when the clubs first met in a friendly played on Tottenham Marshes. Arsenal, then called Royal Arsenal, had been formed just a year earlier as Dial Square and were essentially the works team for the munitions factory situated in Woolwich, Kent, while Spurs who had been formed some five years earlier in 1882 still had many of the youngsters who founded the club playing for them. Spurs won that first encounter 2-1, although the game was cut short by 15 minutes, due to poor light conditions because of the Arsenal team getting lost and turning-up late for the start.

Seven more friendlies were played between the two clubs from 1888 to 1896 with Spurs winning four and Arsenal winning three before their first competitive match in March 1899. By this time, Arsenal were re-named Woolwich Arsenal and the clubs met in the United League with the Gunners winning 2-1 at the Manor Ground in Plumstead while Spurs won the return match 3-2 at Northumberland Park.

Two matches were played within the same week in April 1900 in the Southern District Combination League with Spurs winning 4-2 at White Hart Lane which was followed by a 2-1 win to Arsenal at Plumstead in a game abandoned after 75 minutes due to "bad language". History doesn't provide the answer as to who was the guilty party! From 1901 to 1920, the clubs met in various minor competitions, friendlies and matches played during the First World War.

Tottenham Hotspur joined the Football League in season 1908-09 and won promotion to the First Division on their first attempt. The following season they played Arsenal in December 1909 and lost 0-1 at the Manor Ground in Plumstead, while the reverse fixture at White Hart Lane ended in a 1-1 draw with John Curtis scoring Spurs' first League goal against the Gunners.

The teams met for three more seasons before Arsenal's relegation at the end of the 1912-13 season with Spurs winning three matches, Arsenal winning two and one game drawn.

September 1913 proved to be a hugely important date in the history of both clubs as Arsenal controversially moved from south of the River Thames into the territory reserved for Tottenham Hotspur and Clapton (later Leyton) Orient, in clear violation of the rules and regulations governing such relocations as stipulated by the Football League. Despite bitter protests, Arsenal's move to Highbury (more correctly called Arsenal Stadium) was allowed.

White Hart Lane was requisitioned by the Army during WWI, so Spurs played many of their wartime matches at Highbury.

When League football resumed after the war in 1919, it was decided to once again expand the First Division from 20 teams to 22. The normal way of doing this had always been to add the top two clubs from the Second Division to those who were already in the First Division. However, there were complications arising from allegations of match-fixing from Liverpool and Manchester United during the final matches of the last season played before the League was suspended and it was felt that they would forfit their Top Flight status as a result.

From nowhere, Arsenal, who had finished sixth (later corrected to fifth) in the Second Division before the war were 'elected' to take Tottenham Hotspur's place in the First Division. Allegations of bribery persist to this day and Henry Norris (Arsenal's Chairman) was later given a lifetime ban from football from the Football League for underhand financial activities.

Spurs and Arsenal played their first Football League match after World War One in the First Division in January 1921 with Spurs winning 2-1 at White Hart Lane while Arsenal won the return match at Highbury 3-2. All 150 League games played to date have taken place in the Top Flight of English football.

Highbury was taken over by the Army during the Second World War and Spurs returned the favour by allowing Arsenal to play their wartime matches at White Hart Lane. Arsenal won the first FA Cup meeting between the two teams 3-0 in the 3rd Round in January 1949. The clubs have played five FA Cup matches to date with Spurs winning two and Arsenal winning three.

The first Football League Cup match took place in November 1968 with Arsenal winning the first leg of the Semi-Final 1-0 at Highbury and Spurs drawing 1-1 at White Hart Lane the following month. Of the 12 League Cup matches played so far, Spurs have won 3, Arsenal have won 6 and three games have been drawn.

Both Arsenal and Tottenham Hotspur were founder members of the Premier League in season 1992-93 and both clubs are among the seven (Liverpool, Everton, Chelsea, Manchester United and Aston Villa are the other five) who have been ever-present during the 21 seasons of the competition.

Arsenal went two goals ahead by halftime in the 2010-11 fixture at the Emirates in November through Samir Nasri and Marouane Chamakh but Spurs came back strongly with goals from Gareth Bale, Rafael van der Vaart (penalty) and Younes Kaboul to secure a 3-2 win.

The match at White Hart Lane in April 2011 was a six goal thriller with honours even. Theo Walcott and Rafael van der Vaart scored goals within the first 10 minutes before Samir Nasri put the Gunners 2-1 up after 12 minutes. Arsenal went further ahead with a Robin van Persie goal on 40 minutes but Tom Huddlestone made it 2-3 by halftime. Van der Vaart scored the only goal in the second half from the penalty spot.

The fixture at White Hart Lane in October 2011 was won by Spurs 2-1 with goals from Rafael van der Vaart and Kyle Walker with Aaron Ramsey scoring for Arsenal. The Gunners won their home match in February 2012 5-2. Louis Saha had put Spurs ahead after 4 minutes and an Emmanuel Adebayor penalty put Tottenham further ahead after 34 minutes. But Arsenal pulled two goals back before half-time through Bacary Sagna and Robin van Persie. Tomas Rosicky put Arsenal in front just after the break and the rout was completed with a brace from Theo Walcott.

During the 2012 summer transfer window, Spurs signed former Arsenal striker Emmanuel Adebayor from Manchester City after having spent a season on loan.

The match on 17th November at the Emirates resulted in a 5-2 win for Arsenal. Emmanuel Adebayor put Spurs ahead after 10 minutes but was sent-off eight minutes later for a rash tackle on Santi Cazorla. Arsenal then scored three times to make it 3-1 at halftime - Per Mertesacker, Lukas Podolski and Olivier Giroud grabbing the goals. Santi Cazorla put Arsenal further ahead on the hour mark but Gareth Bale pulled one back for Spurs before Theo Walcott scored the fifth for Arsenal just before the final whistle.

Spurs won the match at the Lane in March 2013 2-1 with Gareth Bale scoring after 37 minutes and Aaron Lennon adding a second two minutes later. Per Mertesacker pulled a goal back for Arsenal six minutes into the second half.

Olivier Giroud scored in the 23rd minute to give Arsenal the points in the September 2013 Premier League game at the Emirates.

Arsenal ran-out 2-0 winners in the FA Cup 3rd Round match played at the Emirates in January 2014 with Santi Cazorla & Tomas Rosicky scoring a goal each.

As far as Football League / Premier League matches go, three player have both scored nine goals for Spurs against Arsenal - Billy Minter and Bobby Smith.

Three Arsenal players have each scored eight goals against Spurs - Robert Pires, Emmanuel Adebayor and Alan Smith.

There have been three hat-tricks scored during North London Derbies - Terry Dyson for Spurs and Ted Drake & Alan Sunderland for Arsenal.

Jimmy Robertson & Emmanuel Adebayor are the only two players to score for both Spurs & Arsenal in a North London Derby.

Arsenal's David O'Leary has played in the most North London Derbies (35) while both Gary Mabbutt & Steve Perryman played 31 games with Spurs.

Overall, Spurs have won 91 of the 253 matches played against Arsenal with the Gunners winning 103 and 59 matches drawn.

author: StripiestPilot
content:
[QUOTE][url=http://www.tottenhamhotspurs.tv/forum/showthread.php?p=949775]Originally Posted by Don Diaz[/url]
I like this but I'm not sure Dembele is fit and I'd prefer Lennon left and Townsend right. My other current fear is Sandro, since he's been back and especially watching him first hand at Chelsea and last night on TV, he just seems to tear around the pitch mis-timing tackles. If we suffer another sending off in this game I fear an onslaught.

Please god just win this one, don't care how, who with or how many.[/QUOTE]

Sandro is the least of our problems, we need players who can fight. Against Benfica Sandro only got booked because he had no other choice, Eriksen took such a bad free kick that we almost conceded on the break. With a few more minutes his tackling will be back to normal. Most important thing in this game is that we keep a clean sheet, I expect Bentaleb will come in to partner Sandro if Dembele doesn't make it, he was one of our only decent players against Chelsea.

Being realistic we should accept that there isn't much more these players can do. Some of them are carrying knocks, some of them haven't adjusted to the league, some of them are only just back from lengthy injuries, some missed pre-season, some haven't adapted to the change in manager, there are so many things working against us at the moment. We need to keep working hard with an eye on making a real challenge for the top 4 next season. It's March and we still don't know our best XI, that is the biggest difference between us and the current top 4. We have no idea what our best team is and as a result no real understanding has developed on the pitch.

[QUOTE][url=http://www.tottenhamhotspurs.tv/forum/showthread.php?p=950085]Originally Posted by ParkLaneMal[/url]
Thanks DSF, that's the kick up the arse, excuse the pun, I needed after Thursday's debacle. I will be positive, honest but only after a couple of beers in the Gilpin. COYS[/QUOTE]Talking about pubs makes me THIRSTY! I know I shouldn't but I might just drop in there as well - my train gets into Waterloo at 2 o'clock so I'll have a bit of time to kill. "No Dorset no!" my sensible brain is shouting at me "you know what will happen if you go for a pint before the game, that will end up as 10 pints and chasers and blood will flow" - then the other part of my brain joins in - "fukk it Dorset don't listen to that Nancy-boy get a few in mate!". Then yet another part of my brain says "Don't ask me WTF do I know, you killed me with alcohol years ago!"

I can not be anything but positive, why would I pay all that money and do all that nasty travelling if I expected us to get mullahed? I've said it before - expecting the worst is mathematically stupid:

Pre Match Victory Defeat

[TR] Expect Defeat :18: :001_302: [TD][TABLE] :18:
[/TD][/TR][TR] Expect Victory :001_302: :001_302: [TD][TABLE] :18:
[/TD][/TR]

See? You can only possibly get ONE smiley face if you expect defeat, BUT you can get TWO smiley faces if you are optimistic. Expecting defeat gives you a grumpy Face before the match whatever happens, so even WHEN we win you will only have balanced out the faces and you will have a Neutral 'Bleeeaa' face : :20:. If on the other hand you are optimistic then WHEN we win you will have a double smiley face.

author: Bogota Yid
content:
If all fit I'd go...

Lloris
Walker Kaboul Vertonghen Rose
Sandro Dembele
Lennon Eriksen Chadll(or Townsend)
Adebayor

Lennon has been crap recently but I'm not sure who else is any better there, Townsend will just cut inside and blast 2 miles over. I'd prefer him on the left as a traditional winger and try to whip crosses in, but I'd probably just choose Chadli as I feel we will need defensive cover on that side(as we will everywhere for this game!).
If Dembele isn't fit then I'd play Bentaleb. Paulinho is better against mid or low placed league sides where he has more license to get forward. This is definitley not the game for him to start in a deeper position.
Ir Rose isn't fit, then for fcks sake lets just play Fryers there, not Naughton and keep Jan in his preferred position.

However, the only really thing that will make me want to smash things up if it doesn't happen, is if Eriksen doesn't start behind the striker. Every man and his dog that has half a functional brain can see this is where he should play, just please do it Tim.

I'm pretty much done for this season, I just hope we can salvage some pride in this game. Even if we win, i can't see us getting 4th. They will drop more points but doubt it will be enough as so will we. The only thing keeping me optimistic for this game is that we are so bad at the moment and I fully expect them to win, and the reason for that is that football is a funny old game and on so many occasions a surprise pops up when you least expect it. But if things go as I expect, then I think we will get shafted.

author: kawa
content:
[QUOTE][url=http://www.tottenhamhotspurs.tv/forum/showthread.php?p=950155]Originally Posted by Coach Yohan 22[/url]
Wenger afraid of LVG .. ![/QUOTE]

LVG manages the likes of Ajax, Barcelona and Bayern Munich. It would be totally stupendous if he managed our pokey old club.

At Bayern, he brought in Robben, promoted Thomas Müller and Badstuber to the first team, and turned Schweinsteiger in to a CDM (from a winger!). He's had a massive impact on the Bayern team of today. He took them to the Champions League final where they lost to Mourinho's Inter.

If I was Wenger, I would be afraid. Right now, the only top-class managers in the country are Wenger himself and Mourinho. LVG is absolutely in that class.

He's not an immediate-impact manager, though - his teams are known for needing time to understand how he wants them to play. If we're patient with him, he can take us to the next level. No question.

author: CrimsonGunner11
content:
[quote]
Tottenham's Emmanuel Adebayor says pressure gets to Arsenal ahead of North London derby


Emmanuel Adebayor does not believe Arsenal can handle pressure and has called on his Tottenham Hotspur team-mates to take the fight to the Gunners in Sunday's North London derby.

The capital rivals lock horns at White Hart Lane this weekend in a vital clash for both sides, as Spurs look to keep their top-four hopes alive and Arsenal strive to stay in touch with Premier League leaders Chelsea.

Adebayor played for Arsenal for three years and admires the way Arsene Wenger's team play, but believes there are weaknesses that can be exploited due to a lack of tenacious midfielders.

He told the Daily Mirror: "Arsenal are a good team when they have the ball. When they don't, they are not that good. When you put them under pressure, they can't handle it.

"They don't have a lot of physical presence. Apart from Flamini, I don't see anyone who puts themselves into a proper battle.

"Rosicky is not that type of player, Cazorla is not the type of player who defends. Arteta is trying to do it, but that's not his job.

"They don't have anybody who can say, 'if I have to kick, I will kick. If we have to fight, I will put myself at the front of it'. That's how we have to play. Push them and force them to make errors."

The character of some of Tottenham's own players has been called into question by boss Tim Sherwood after a couple of demoralising defeats this week, with a 4-0 drubbing at Chelsea followed by a 3-1 loss at home to Benfica in the Europa League.

Adebayor accepts that Spurs have not shown enough hunger in certain games, but says there will be no problem with motivation on Sunday.

He said: "In some games, some players, including me - I have to include myself - we have lacked that personality. We have lacked that desire and things have gone wrong.

"That's why we have to look into the mirror and say, 'OK, I judge myself, I didn't play well today, but in the next game I will be better'.

"On Sunday I don't even think we will need a team meeting.

"There are some games where you have to give a little bit of motivation to the players. But we know how good we are at home when it comes to Arsenal and we won't have to motivate anybody for this game."

Adebayor added: "The is the game that everybody will be talking about in London from this point," said the striker, "Tottenham v Arsenal: The north London derby.

"So I cannot see anybody telling me, 'Manu, you have to run. You have to give 100 per cent'.

"No one will need to tell me that. I know. And people like Aaron Lennon, who has been here for ages, you won't have to tell players like him anything either. He knows how big it is for the club and the fans. To be honest with you, we are all looking forward to it."[/quote]

Source: [url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11670/9214573/tottenhams-emmanuel-adebayor-says-pressure-gets-to-arsenal-ahead-of-north-london-derby]http://www1.skysports.com/football/news ... ndon-derby[/url]

content:

LVG manages the likes of Ajax, Barcelona and Bayern Munich. It would be totally stupendous if he managed our pokey old club.

At Bayern, he brought in Robben, promoted Thomas Müller and Badstuber to the first team, and turned Schweinsteiger in to a CDM (from a winger!). He's had a massive impact on the Bayern team of today. He took them to the Champions League final where they lost to Mourinho's Inter.

If I was Wenger, I would be afraid. Right now, the only top-class managers in the country are Wenger himself and Mourinho. LVG is absolutely in that class.

He's not an immediate-impact manager, though - his teams are known for needing time to understand how he wants them to play. If we're patient with him, he can take us to the next level. No question.[/QUOTE]

Unfortunately patience is something Levy appears to lack.

author: P3nnyw1se
content:
Goodluck spurs from a danish fan..
Sadly I won't be able to see the game, as we are having our own 'mini' version of your derby in the danish league
my team 'Aalborg 1885 aka Aab' played champions league 4 years ago,
beat city 2-0 and played 2-2 at old trafford, with probably 1/10000th the player salary.
We have been in a financial crises ever since and almost went bankrupt last year,
the club is literally not able to sign players anymore, last season we couldn't even afford to loan
only way to survive was the accademy, hope some young talents would make the team

And today after nearly relegating for 3 years in a row, we're suddenly no.2 in the league
with the youngest lineup ever, all home grown kids.
We already sold talents in 2013 to Juventus, Ajax and Aston Villa.
And scouts from all over the world is watching this team of teenagers every game.


We even got our own 'mini' Eriksen, a creative playmaker 'Kasper Kusk' playing as a winger
He just made the national side and played 45minutes against you guys a few weeks ago.
[url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_o1Kvw-2yOA]Kasper Kusk - Great Danish Talent - YouTube[/url]
Rumour is Dortmund scouts are following him closely now.
Him and Eriksen will in my opinion be perfect playing side by side.



Anyways: Today, at the same time as your derby
we are playing no.1 in the league
A young rich and ambitious club just 20 miles from Aab.
we have 2 champions league spots in Denmark, and we would like to get one of those.
Our entire future might even depend on it.
anyways Goodluck, COYS!

author: fuego
content:
[QUOTE][url=http://www.tottenhamhotspurs.tv/forum/showthread.php?p=950385]Originally Posted by koppel[/url]
I believe Capoue is still injured so expect Sandro in his place. I agree with your lineup except for Soldado. I'd start Adebayor.

We really need Dembele in there because for all his tricks and flicks Paulinho seems incapable of retaining the ball these days and that's exactly what Dembele does best and will need to do against Arsenal. Eriksen centrally is vital, we can't waste him on the left. We need him in between Flamini and their backline where he can hurt them.[/QUOTE]
The reason I didn't pick Adebayor is because I believe he is too high risk in a game against Arsenal. He also hasn't been that effective in the last few games. Soldado needs to play a few times with a line-up that can deliver the right type of service to make him effective. We can't keep limping along with a single striker, who may, or may not decide to turn up, or may get himself a red card during the match. We also need to know (for sure) whether we are going to keep, or replace Soldado, come the summer.

There is an argument that if we can't win the EL and we can't get 5th or better, that we should use the remaining matches to try and prepare ourselves for next season. I.e. as a means to finding solutions for our current issues. Maybe it's still too early to do so. By next weekend, however, we should know for sure.

90% of Spurs fans seem to fancy him. The dude can't play football, just throws himself at the opposition and gives away fouls in dangerous areas. No skill, no end product, not good on the ball and for a big dude, doesn't have great poise. First step this club needs to take in its regeneration is to start playing footballers, not personalties.[/QUOTE]

So true. Though when fit I think Sandro offers something and can be very useful. However, he's been fit so rarely in his Spurs career. A player needs 10 games to get properly match fit and Sandro is one of those players that struggles to do that. I like the the guy, but if he were to be sold, I'd want us to sign a more technical footballer to replace him. From now on, no matter what their role in the team is, everyone we sign should be comfortable on the ball and be able to pass it around at a high tempo.

author: Arsenal~Fanatic
content: Outstanding result. Super chuffed with the result but some of our players need to take a long hard look at themselves. Koscielny and Mertesacker bailed us out with countless clearances and interceptions. I don't care how we got the result but it was a pretty poor display in terms of keeping possession and doing simple things. We had major issues keeping hold of the ball in our own half. it was good that Chadli was playing as our undercover agent. Adebayor had a brilliant game for them but he too fluffed a couple of chances. Wenger should have adopted a more measured approach by brining in Flamini at half time. Spurs were all over us in the second half. Wenger's reluctance to ring in changes in a proactive manner is really irritating. Happy to see Spurs being relegated to play Europa league yet again. not too positive about our title chances especially with the kind of performance put in today. Nice to see us ensure Wenger trophy for yet another season.

They are so far ahead of us in terms of individual quality yet we still beat them in possession and forced them to park the bus. You can't be angry with the players they gave it there all. As for Sherwood? I thought he did great! We played great stuff and put them under serious pressure. At the end of the day we don't have the players who can unlock a Champions League level defence and the only one who has a hope of even sniffing a goal is Adebayor. This isn't the players fault, this isn't Sherwoods faul, this is Levy and Baldinis fault for buying these players. We need to rebuild in the Summer with players who are quick, strong and can finish. We need to build the team around Christian Eriksen because he can make magic happen. It is embarrassing to lose to that lot, it is hurtful but at least we gave it our all!

author: meniscus
content: whilst I'm disappointed in the loss, I'm just glad we didn't just lie down and cop a thumping after they scored so early.  All the usual issues that have plagued our entire season still remain, so there's no point in re-treading the same ground, pointing fingers, etc.   What I am interested in, is how the team responds for the remaining season, given how little we have to play for now. Who is going to prove their worth for next season?

author: kirkieb
content:
Stop playing Eriksen and Townsend out of fcking position. Eriksen needs to operate centrally period! The team must be built around Eriksen. I don't rate Paulino he's too slow. Soldado should have come in at Half time Ade needed the help.
TS waits too late to make his substitutions.

author: AzzaTHFC
content: The disappointing thing is that Arsenal were there for the taking, they looked heavy in the legs from Tuesday's CL game in Munich. We looked solid defensively for once which was great to see but we offered little to nothing in attack, we were bereft of ideas. L'arse looked comfortable defending against our attacks, we resulted in long balls.

author: TommyBee
content:
[QUOTE][url=http://www.tottenhamhotspurs.tv/forum/showthread.php?p=951025]Originally Posted by Coach Yohan 22[/url]
Yeah mate , but he confirmed that before the game against ars ( fa cup )[/QUOTE]

Sherwood's feelings for Arsenal as a kid is not stopping him from doing his best with Spurs. I think the problem is that his best isn't good enough, either that or half the squad has been beaten with the dumb stick because it isn't really looking like they have a decent plan. So either it's the manager's plan that's lacking or the manager has a fan-oh-tastic plan that the players aren't managing to put to life. We are not scoring goals, and we're generally hardly creating clear cut chances or sometimes we even struggle to string three passes together against mediocre opposition. I mean our goal difference is pathetic and while it's been a tad better under Tim it's still pretty awful and we're about as entertaining to look at as rain.

Today we at least played well and it's nearly a miracle that we didn't get two-three goals, and yet another miracle that we only conceded once. It's not a new thing that Spurs buckle under pressure so I guess we should've expected a little less from this season as the pressure was insane from the start.

I think they boo'ed the decision to take eriksen off.

at least that's what I got from watching it on TV.

author: Ben_THFC
content: I think we missed Walker today, Naughton played well, but width was desperately needed with townsend cutting into trouble and Walker is a good outball. Rose did well on the other side in the first half, but final ball is terrible. The high line was suicidal with no pressure for opening half hour but with an increase in tempo we saw the benefits of this system as it pinned them back. Unfortunately they kinda put backs to the wall in second half, closing up the space available in the first half and forcing us to use possession effectively, a fault of ours all season. Eriksen didn't really affect the game from the left but to me the subs were pointless. Straight swap Sandro for Pauly I understand. Siggy though has little impact barring goals which he wasnt in a position to get most of the time. Soldado perhaps should have been introduced earlier but not for eriksen, as with a front two and a midfield pairing of Paulinho/Bentaleb we simply couldnt create good chances and ultimately ran out of steam. Thats my lot.

content: [url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ybMK-gp5t0Q]YouTube Video[/url]

author: KING-11
content:
TS has done everything right with the line-up. It was the players who coudn't score. And I think the reason Chadli missed his chance, was the lack of confiedence. He rarely starts for us. If we had played him throughout the season, he would've scored those.
Even if TS now can't get us to the CL, he can make the highest points tally of the club.

Anyway, we should now try to win Benfica, players have the quality to do that. I really think it can happen.

author: gauntarchie
content:
We obviously played better today. But let's be honest here Arsenal were pretty well missing half there first choice midfield and from what i gathered. Bayern Munich ran them off the park and were buggered when they got back to London. We couldn't even break them down and get a goal at home. That aint good, I didn't think the team selection was that bad today. But seriously this was a must win for us. Arsenal were depleted, we are at home. Why would we not go in with two strikers. Sherwood always said he'd go for it. But he is playing like a man who doesn't want to get thumped.

Today there were countless times we got the ball to the by-line cut it back and their was no one in the box. If Chadli is going to play that number 10 role he has to be more prevalent in the box. I just felt he was dropping too deep and not helping adebayor. Adebayor really needed the help and was just not getting it. The other thing is why Sherwood is making his subs so late. What is the point in making the subs in the 80th minute. Why take off Chadli, Erikson, Sandro and Put on Siggy and Paulinho. We are chasing a game we need creativity. Take off Chadli and put Soldado up front with Ade. If i had missed the subs i would never have known he made three subs, they were truly ineffective and we became very easy to predict.

On the plus side. I think Naughton had a good game, Defensively i think he's better than Walker on the right. Obviously not quite up there in attack but i think he keeps a level head a bit better than Walker. Rose also did a good job, people keep talking about the final product but who was there to pass to. 1 attacker in the box and 4 defenders. Your just never going to pick out your player.
Townsend is a funny one, he gets himself into some awesome positions but then almost tries to hard. Some of the balls he crossed just didn't need to be hit that hard. Just pass it to the players fit dont blast it across goal.

I don't really know what to make of Chadli, i think two upfront is just hands down a better option for a team who are struggling so much to put the ball in the net. this 4-3-3 stuff is so heavily reliant on the wingers being absolute class, and having the knowledge to support the striker in the box. Our wingers just dont look threatening in the box. Half the time i'm gobsmacked at how many of spurs players are not making that final run to the far post or just hanging around the top of the box. Like make a ****ing run, take a chance. At the very least it forces one of the defenders to not concentrate soley on ade.

I dunno thats my thoughts, i think pretty well everyone can see after playing over 3 quarters of the season with a 4-3-3. It is not suiting us at home. Maybe away but at home two strikers up front is imperative from the start. And for the sake of my own sanity, when we are behind in a game stop taking off creative players and putting on players who can close out a game. When we are ahead put on defensive players. For me though TS is so far out of his depth it aint funny. I'm all for giving manager's a chance and all. But i think the hallmark of a good manager is their ability to change the game with subs. Can't really remember an effective sub TS has made in 4 months.

author: northspur
content: Player splayed well but the subs must be looked at. Soldado should have come on early when we was going all out against them and given him 30 mins he has the most assists in the prem this year. But instead Sherwood gives him 10 mins to make an impact. At 60 mins it was the perfect time to maybe take Bentaleb off and bring on an attacking player and went all out for the win or the minimum the draw. Sherwoods logic is mind blowing in what he sees and everyone else sees to try to change the game.

Eriksen naturally and rightly floats into the centre of the pitch leaving rose to cover two players. Then if Rose pushes up on their right back it means Jan has to come across to the left midfielder exposing a hole in the heart of our defence.

No fault of the players, the fault lies at not having a natural left winger who fully understands the role rather than a makeshift winger using a central midfielder - something that hasn't been addressed since Bale moved into the CAM role middle of last season.

author: BrooklynYid
content: Took the day off from here yesterday because I figured things got ugly.  My thoughts are that at least we played hard and didn't quit.  That is at least something to build on a smidge.  I don't know, we are just not that good it seems.  Even Eriksen and Ade aren't world beaters.  I really want Soldado to be a success but i just don't see it.  I'm afraid what will happen to this team in the summer.  Could be totally dismantled.  Would be nice if we hung on to fifth though.  Small victories.

author: special_one_not
content:
That game summed up perfectly our current troubles; we had most of the possession, we had most shots on goal and we spent vastly the most amount of time in arse's half. Yet we were impotent. Arse had more shots on target than we did and the clearest chances, despite being on the back foot most of the game and despite missing many good players. We just huffed and puffed without effect for most of the game. We enjoyed a new manager bounce for a bit but that's now evaporated and this could have been a late avb performance.
We need even a weakened arse's creativity and we need speed, we're too ploddy and predictable in our approach play and defensively we look likely to concede every time. Ade spend too much time deep coming for the ball or out on the wings and only seems to go upfront when we start playing like Wimbledon and hoofing long balls from the back. Not surprisingly the lads lack confidence which isn't helping but were too predictable. Likely TS will be gone once this forgettable season ends, we need a fresh start with an experienced coach who can take us forward rather than sideways. We need to study the Liverpool model and accept a season or two of building with a PROVEN coach No more cheapskate gambles Mr Levy. Let's get it right next time, no more gambles.

author: Joeterror13
content:
[QUOTE][url=http://www.tottenhamhotspurs.tv/forum/showthread.php?p=951143]Originally Posted by gauntarchie[/url]
We obviously played better today. But let's be honest here Arsenal were pretty well missing half there first choice midfield and from what i gathered. Bayern Munich ran them off the park and were buggered when they got back to London. We couldn't even break them down and get a goal at home. That aint good, I didn't think the team selection was that bad today. But seriously this was a must win for us. Arsenal were depleted, we are at home. Why would we not go in with two strikers. Sherwood always said he'd go for it. But he is playing like a man who doesn't want to get thumped.

Today there were countless times we got the ball to the by-line cut it back and their was no one in the box. If Chadli is going to play that number 10 role he has to be more prevalent in the box. I just felt he was dropping too deep and not helping adebayor. Adebayor really needed the help and was just not getting it. The other thing is why Sherwood is making his subs so late. What is the point in making the subs in the 80th minute. Why take off Chadli, Erikson, Sandro and Put on Siggy and Paulinho. We are chasing a game we need creativity. Take off Chadli and put Soldado up front with Ade. If i had missed the subs i would never have known he made three subs, they were truly ineffective and we became very easy to predict.

On the plus side. I think Naughton had a good game, Defensively i think he's better than Walker on the right. Obviously not quite up there in attack but i think he keeps a level head a bit better than Walker. Rose also did a good job, people keep talking about the final product but who was there to pass to. 1 attacker in the box and 4 defenders. Your just never going to pick out your player.
Townsend is a funny one, he gets himself into some awesome positions but then almost tries to hard. Some of the balls he crossed just didn't need to be hit that hard. Just pass it to the players fit dont blast it across goal.

I don't really know what to make of Chadli, i think two upfront is just hands down a better option for a team who are struggling so much to put the ball in the net. this 4-3-3 stuff is so heavily reliant on the wingers being absolute class, and having the knowledge to support the striker in the box. Our wingers just dont look threatening in the box. Half the time i'm gobsmacked at how many of spurs players are not making that final run to the far post or just hanging around the top of the box. Like make a ****ing run, take a chance. At the very least it forces one of the defenders to not concentrate soley on ade.

I dunno thats my thoughts, i think pretty well everyone can see after playing over 3 quarters of the season with a 4-3-3. It is not suiting us at home. Maybe away but at home two strikers up front is imperative from the start. And for the sake of my own sanity, when we are behind in a game stop taking off creative players and putting on players who can close out a game. When we are ahead put on defensive players. For me though TS is so far out of his depth it aint funny. I'm all for giving manager's a chance and all. But i think the hallmark of a good manager is their ability to change the game with subs. Can't really remember an effective sub TS has made in 4 months.[/QUOTE]

brilliant summed up article and spot on. I just wish Timmy and the players are listening.

author: Zinc
content: If Chamberlain had bought his shooting boots this could have looked like a convincing win. We went with a conservative game plan, didn't quite pull it off fully so the second half was intense but we came away with 3 points. In years past we've had the performance but not the result, I'm more than happy winning ugly from now until the end of the season.

author: mrunderwear
content:
Terrible team shape at the moment!

We have quality CB in Kaboul and Vertonghen but Sandro not our answer.

Bentaleb is inexperienced, even though he is able to pick out players.

I rather we stick w Livermore as DM, Holtby,Bentaleb and Carroll competing for the CM spot

Adebayor has put in a great shift! lets hope he plays his heart out more.

Townsend brings so much to Spurs than Lennon/Lamela. You see the urgency from him- RECEIVES BALL, SPRINT AND GO. only Ade was in his way delaying his attacks.

Lloris can go if he wants to, we need a calmer keeper, often there are options for him to play a short pass instead of punting it forward, his distribution is atrocious.

Neuer, for example doesnt have the best ball control skills, but he remains calm and distribute very well w his feet.

Walker isnt missed, Naughton delivered more crosses than Walker! Kept things simple when attacking
